item.description: Windows RDP Event Logs On source machine: SecurityğŸ›¡ï¸ (4648) TerminalServices-RDPClient ğŸŒ¸ (1024 and 1102) On the target machine: Security ğŸ›¡ï¸ (4624, logon type 10, 4778 and 4779), see Session name to confirm it’s an RDP.

item.title: ğŸ¤” How Do I Check For Logs Clearing?
item.description: Windows â—ï¸These techniques require admin or higher privileges. â—ï¸Common with ransomware When the Security trail is deleted, 1102 is usually created afterwards.

item.title: ğŸ¤” How Do I Check For Malicious Autostarts?
item.description: Windows Tasks Event logs Two trails are of use are Microsoft-Windows-TaskScheduler/Operational ğŸ‡ (disabled by default on the newer systems) and Security ğŸ›¡ï¸.

item.title: ğŸ¤” How Do I Check For Reconnaisance Activity?
item.description: Windows Event logs Monitoring for these events will cause a lot of noise and false positives.

item.title: ğŸ¤” How do I check program execution?
item.description: Windows You can use Prefetch which is the most reliable source. However, if the program is NOT there, it doesn’t mean it wasn’t executed.

item.title: ğŸ¤” How Do I Check System Information?
item.description: Windows Registry, of course. AmCache, Registry ğŸ—„ï¸ You can see firmware, hardware and OS info there.

item.title: ğŸ¤” How Do I Find Malicious or Compromised Accounts?
item.description: Windows Event logs It starts with the event 4720 (account created) and multiple 4732 events (member added to some security-enabled group).

item.title: ğŸ¤” How Do I investigate logon events?
item.description: Windows Event Logs There is a fine line between logon and account logon events, and that line is not just one word.

item.title: ğŸ¤” How Do I Spot Bruteforcing Activity?
item.description: Windows Event logs There will be no shortage of 4625 events (unsuccessful login) showing up in the logs.
